table_items.text: GUIDELINE FOR PERFORMING THE 11 WEEKS AND 2 DAYS TO 14 WEEKS AND 1 DAY ULTRASOUND SCAN
Clinical Guideline Register No: 11030 Status: Public
Model of Best Practice 2007-2010 - Down's syndrome screening , from DoH
Specialist Midwife for Guidelines and Audit
Lead Consultant for Obstetrics and Gynaecology
Policy to be followed by (target staff)
Intranet and hard copies to be kept in the ultrasound department.
Related Trust Policies (to be read in conjunction with)
04071 Infection Control Policy 04071 Standard Infection Prevention 04072 Hand Hygiene 05118 Chaperone Policy 04064 Safeguarding Children Policy

Purpose
To ensure that staff know the procedures to follow for the 11 weeks and 2 days to 14 weeks and 1 day scan.
The purpose of the scan is to:
Confirm viable pregnancy
Diagnose a multiple pregnancy
Calculate an Estimated Date of Delivery (EDD).
Check for normal development of fetal anatomy (see point 8.0 )
Check for any abnormal development
Scope
This document encompasses all women who consent for the 11 weeks and 2 days to 14 weeks and 1 day scan.
Aims
Ensure access to a uniform screening programme which conforms to an agreed level of quality.
Provide appropriate information for women so that they are able to make an informed choice about their screening options and pregnancy management.
Identify serious fetal abnormalities, either incompatible with life or associated with morbidity, allowing women to make reproductive choices.
Identify certain abnormalities that may benefit from antenatal intervention or early intervention following delivery.
Background

Nuchal translucency (NT) screening was introduced by the government as part of a national Screening programme to improve the detection rate of Down's Syndrome (T21), and this has been extended to include Patau's Syndrome (T13) and Edward's syndrome (T18).
Equality and Diversity

Mid Essex Hospital Services NHS Trust is committed to the provision of a service that is fair, accessible and meets the needs of all individuals. An Equality Impact Assessment is attached as Appendix B.
Procedure
Verbal consent must be obtained for all examinations. Additional verbal consent should be obtained where a student Sonographer undertakes part or all of the ultrasound examination under supervision.

One accompanying adult will be invited into the scan room during the anatomical checks. Children will not be admitted into the scan room until all of the checks have been completed. Any other people accompanying the patient, including children will be allowed to view the scan once the Sonographer is happy the scan is complete.

A formal chaperone must be present whenever an intimate examination/procedure is to take place, regardless of the gender of the examiner. A chaperone will be provided for the patient according to the Trust's chaperone policy (50118).

First trimester combined screening will be offered to all patients who present for ultrasound scan between 11 weeks and 2 days to 14 weeks and 1 day, where Crown Rump length (CRL) measurements are between 45-84mm inclusive. For CRL criteria and NT criteria refer to appendix A and appendix B.

Second trimester serum screening will be offered to women who present at ultrasound scan with a CRL of greater than 84mm, where the HC measures 14 weeks and 0 days to 20 weeks and 0 days (where the head circumference measurement is equal to or greater than 98mm (14 weeks and 0 days.) This is in keeping with NICE guidelines. The second trimester screening is for Down's Syndrome only and does not included Patau's and Edwards Syndrome.

To offer appropriate tests and methods of screening that meet national standards. Mid Essex screening is primarily offered in the firsttrimester using the combined nuchal translucency (NT) and biochemical serum screening. Results are measured in terms of risk. Results are classed as high risk when the risk is greater or equal to a nationally agreed cut-off number. A cut off of 1 in 150 is used as a cut off for both firsttrimester screening and secondtrimester screening.
All patients must give informed consent prior to having the screening. This should be given after discussion with midwife who completes part of the blood test form:
Patients can choose not to have any screening
They can choose to have T21 screening only
T13/T18 screening only
Screening for all three conditions (T21 and T13/ T18)
The blood test form is to be completed by the Sonographer, who must enter their FMF/DQASS code on the form.

The patient should be advised to have the blood test on the same day after the scan for first and second trimester screening. The patient should be weighed by the Sonographer and this should be written on the blood form
Chronicity must be written on the blood form if twins are found

Where fetal size exceeds a CRL of 84mm and HC measures 98mm or less. The CRL measurement will be used for second trimester screening. The patient should be instructed to attend for second trimester screening after they are 14 weeks and 2 days gestation.

A transvaginal ultrasound scan may be performed during the examination. Refer to ‘The infection control procedure' for the decontamination of intercavity and non-intracavity transducers (posted in ultrasound rooms and on the S drive, also in appendix C). Before performing any intimate examinations all patients must give informed consent prior to having a trans-vaginal scan, also see the Equality impact assessment in Appendix D.

If it is not possible to obtain an accurate NT measurement despite ‘twice on the couch' then further attempts on another day do not have to be offered. The woman should be offered second trimester screening.
Twins / Multiple Fetus Detected on Scan
6.12.1 For Twins, EDD is based on the largest fetus and refer patient to the screening team for further management.

6.12.2 When ultrasound shows that there is an empty second sac, the biochemical markers appear no different to those in a singleton pregnancy and the combined test can be used to calculate the risk. If ultrasound shows there is a second sac containing a fetus with no fetal heart pulsations (‘vanished twin'), it is possible that there could be a contribution to the maternal biochemical markers for many weeks. The risk must be calculated by the laboratory. Therefore blood forms should be completed as ‘Vanished Twin for age and NT risk only'.
6.12.3 st and 2nd Trimester screening cannot be used for any multiple pregnancies greater than two, refer patient to the screening team for further management.

In cases where the woman has already accessed screening via a harmony test prior to her routine dating scan, the scan should be performed for anatomy checks; the NT measurement and screening blood test are not required.
Anatomy to be Assessed
A transverse section of the head should be obtained to demonstrate the skull, midline echo and the choroid plexuses.
A cross-sectional view of the fetal abdomen should be obtained at the level of the stomach sweeping down to the cord insertion to assess the abdominal wall.
The number of limbs present should be determined.
The placental site should be assessed.
The uterus should be assessed for fibroids and adnexae should be assessed for any abnormality.

If the fetal structures cannot be seen, a repeat scan must be booked to exclude any abnormality in 2 weeks' time. Where possible, the NT screening should be performed, as earlier screening yields a more accurate result.
Images to be Recorded

The following images should be captured stored and electronically archived on PACS as a record of the examination. All images should be magnified appropriately. Appendix A and B describe appropriate CRL and NT criteria.
Longitudinal section of the uterus
CRL measurement
Nuchal translucency measurement
Abnormalities
Luteal cysts larger than 4cm
Documentation
There should also be a permanent electronic record of all the imaging studies. Report should include:
EDD (estimated date of delivery)
Presence of fetal heart pulsations.
NT measurement
Any abnormalities
Luteal cysts larger than 4cm
“Cranium and anterior abdominal wall appear intact. Four limbs and normal liquor seen.” (coded text can be used on reporting: USDATA)
If twins are found the chronicity should be included in the report.
Note patient weight at dating scan should be recorded on the report.
The following comment should be typed in the comments section:
Fetal heart pulsations seen
Although fetal structures within our guidelines have been identified, ultrasound alone cannot exclude all chromosomal or genetic abnormalities.
For patients who are above average weight the image quality is reduced due to increased body tissue depth
The coded text is USOBST
Pathway of Care when an Abnormality is Suspected or if Advice is Required

A nuchal translucency (NT) measurement greater than or equal to 3.5mm is a significant early pregnancy scan finding. It is associated with an increased risk of fetal cardiac and chromosomal anomalies.

Referral for specialist scanning and counselling should be considered as good clinical management in all cases where the NT is greater than or equal to 3.5mm (even when screening for Down's syndrome has been declined) - refer patient to the Screening Team for further management.
Contact the Screening Team in the Antenatal Clinic on 01245 513433. Working hours for the Screening Team - Monday – Friday 09.00- 17.00 hours.

If the abnormality is found in the antenatal ultrasound department, the couple should be directed to a quiet room within the ultrasound department and then the Sonographer is to refer patient to the Screening Team for further management.
In cases where the pregnancy is not viable, patients will be supported and referred to the Early Pregnancy Unit on 01245 513037.

If at St. Peter's Hospital, and the Sonographer cannot contact the Screening Team, the Sonographer must assess the severity and urgency of the problem and refer accordingly, either to the ANC or the Screening Team as and when possible, taking the contact telephone number of the woman to pass on to the Screening Team. The woman should also be given the contact details of the Screening Team.
Staff and Training

The procedures should be carried out by suitably qualified Sonographers and/or obstetric staff, possessing the Diploma in Medical Ultrasound (DMU), a Postgraduate Diploma in Medical Ultrasound (PG Dip) or equivalent. Staff performing the 11 weeks and 2 days to 14 weeks and 1 day scan with the nuchal translucency measurement must hold the certificate of competence for the 11 weeks and 2 days to 14 weeks and 1 day scan from the fetal medicine foundation; or the Sonographer must be supervised by a professional who has the certificate. Ultrasound students may carry out ultrasound scans under the supervision of a suitably qualified sonographer.
Infection Prevention
All staff should follow Trust guidelines on infection control. All staff must adhere to the ultrasound specific protocols relating to the cleaning of ultrasound equipment listed in Appendix A.
Audit and Monitoring

Nuchal translucency measurements are subject to internal and external audit. A minimum 90% detection rate with a 2.5% screen positive rate is expected, in keeping with NICE guidelines. To be audited biannually by the Down's Quality assurance support service (DQASS).
Communication - patients
If the nuchal translucency measurement is greater than 3.5mm this should be explained to the patient. Patients should then be referred to the screening midwife.
Following the ultrasound scan, patients are given a written copy of the report.

Following the screening process, patients will receive a written result informing them that their baby has a low risk for Down's Syndrome. If the risk is high, the patient will be contacted by the Screening Team.
Communication- staff
Approved guidelines are published monthly in the Trust's Staff Focus that is sent via email to all staff.
Approved guidelines will be disseminated to appropriate staff via email.
The latest revised guidelines can be accessed via the intranet and clinical guideline folders in each ultrasound room.
References
http://fetalanomaly.screening.nhs.uk/programmestatements Nuchal translucency greater than or equal to 3.5mm. Guidance 22/06/09.
Antenatal Screening - Working standards for Down's syndrome screening 2007 Model of Best Practice 2007-2010 - Down's syndrome screening
Standards for fetal nuchal translucency (NT) measurement for Down's syndrome Screening (2004)
http://fetalanomaly.screening.nhs.uk/standardsandpolicies
http://resources.fetalanomaly.screening.nhs.uk/professional/nuchaltranslucency/?page=1 00372
https://www.gov.uk/government/uploads/system/uploads/attachment_data/file/443865/FA SP_ultrasound_handbook_July_2015_090715.pdf
Screening for Down's syndrome: UK NSC Policy recommendations 2011-2014 Model of Best Practice
Appendix A
Appendix B
Ultrasound Department
Mid Essex Hospital NHS Trust
Infection control procedure for the decontamination of Ultrasound Transducers. For intra-cavity and non-intra-cavity procedures.
Prior to Vaginal Ultrasound Examinations
Ensure the patient is comfortable and relaxed.
Explain the procedure to the patient.
Obtain verbal/written consent from the patient for this procedure.
Confirmation of consent should be documented in the written report or in the patient's notes.
A Chaperone must be present throughout the scan, as per Trust chaperone policy.
If possible lock the door to maintain privacy.
Screen the patient to protect privacy while undressing – using the ceiling mounted curtain or mobile screen.
No one should enter the room, whilst the examination is undertaken.
Equipment
The equipment must be thoroughly cleaned prior to use and decontaminated after use and this should be documented in the written report or patient's notes.
The operators' hands must be washed and/or decontaminated with alcohol gel hand rub both before and after the scan.
Procedure – intra-cavity ultrasound
Examination gloves must be worn when carrying out the scan.
Apply a small amount of gel in the teat of the cover.
Cover the inter-cavity transducer with an ultrasound probe cover (all covers are single use only). Document whether latex or non-latex probe cover is used in the written report or patient's notes.
Use a non-spermicidal probe cover for infertility patients.
Use a latex free probe cover for patients with a latex allergy.
A single use sachet of lubricating gel is to be applied to the end of the inter-cavity transducer.
Undertake the procedure.
Procedure – Non intra-cavity ultrasound
Apply a small amount of gel to the surface of the transducer.
Undertake procedure.
Decontamination of equipment after each procedure
Appendix C

table_items.text: Remove excess gel with a paper tissue
Remove excess gel with a paper tissue

Clean and decontaminate the intra-cavity transducer and cable with a detergent wipe* by: (i) Covering the surface and sides of the transducer with the detergent wipe (ii) Rotate and progress the wipe along the length of the cable. (iii) This step should be repeated with a fresh wipe until the transducer and cable are visibly clean.
Clean all surfaces of the transducer and cable with a detergent wipe*.

Next decontaminate the transducer using Tristel Duo by: (i) Depress the pump once to dispense Duo Foam onto the surface. (ii) Use a paper towel and spread evenly. (iii) Ensure all areas of the surface come into contact with foam. (iv) Leave to dry, allow 30 seconds before contact.
Dry the transducer with a paper tissue
The non-intracavity transducer is now ready for the next patient
*Detergent wipes = Sani-Cloth Multi Surface Detergent Wipes

data.text: Equality Impact Assessment (EIA)
Title of document being impact-assessed: Performing 11 week and 2 days to 14 weeks andday scan

table_items.text: Equality or human rights concern. (see guidance notes below)
Does this item have any differential impact on the equality groups listed? Brief description of impact.
How is this impact being addressed?
Ultrasound scans to assess fetal growth are only possible for female patients as the uterus, and fetus are examined.

Ladies of certain races or ethnicities may choose not to have an internal scan which may be offered if the trans abdominal examination is difficult. Patients may want to have a partner, friend or relative present for the scan. Patients may not want to undress for their scan. Patients may refuse their scan with a certain gender sonographer.

Patients have the right to refuse an internal scan and this is documented on the report. Patients may have one companion during the scan at the scan. This must not affect the concentration of the Sonographer. If the couple bring a child to the examination, then the partner is required to look after the child and not be present during the scan until the examination is completed. Once completed, family members/children are allowed to see the baby once the examination has been completed. A privacy curtain is provided for patients to undress behind. Covers are provided for the patient once undressed to maintain patient dignity. Patients also have a right to refuse examination by Sonographers of either gender. Patients will be rebooked to another list in the first available appointment slot if a suitable Sonographer is not available at the time. Every effort should be made to

data.text: Appendix D

table_items.text: Language may be difficult if the patient's English is limited.

facilitate the patient's understanding of the examination. Family members or friends may be used to translate where available. Translators are available to the Trust and should be used where possible. The Sonographer should decide whether the patient is suitable for the examination if the patient is unable to understand what is involved. This would mean that the patient was not able to fully consent to the scan.
Patients may have differing levels of ability or understanding.

The use of a hoist is available for those with physical disabilities as well as other manual handling tools such as sliding sheets. The procedures are explained to the patient by the Sonographer. The patient has the right to refuse any part of the examination and this should be documented in the report. The Sonographer should decide whether the patient is suitable for the examination if the patient is unable to understand what is involved. This would mean that the patient was not able to fully consent to the scan.
Patients of some religious groups or beliefs may refuse intimate examinations or may request a certain gender of Sonographer.

Patients have the right to refuse any part of the examination and this should be documented on the report. Patients also have a right to refuse examination by Sonographers of either gender. Patients will be rebooked to another list in the first available appointment slot if a suitable Sonographer is not available at the time.
Patients of differing sexual orientations may refuse intimate examinations or may request a certain gender of Sonographer.

Patients have the right to refuse any part of the examination and this should be documented on the report. Patients also have a right to refuse examination by Sonographers of either gender. Patients will be rebooked to another list in the first available appointment slot if a suitable Sonographer is not available at the time.
Patients of any age may refuse intimate examinations or may
Patients have the right to refuse any part of the examination and this
request a certain gender of Sonographer.

should be documented on the report. Patients also have a right to refuse examination by Sonographers of either gender. Patients will be rebooked to another list in the first available appointment slot if a suitable Sonographer is not available at the time.
Transgender patients may refuse intimate examinations or may request a certain gender of Sonographer.

Patients have the right to refuse any part of the examination and this should be documented on the report. Patients also have a right to refuse examination by Sonographers of either gender. Patients will be rebooked to another list in the first available appointment slot if a suitable Sonographer is not available at the time.
Assumptions may be made as to the level of understanding of written guidance. .

The procedures are explained verbally to the patient by the Sonographer. The patient has the right to refuse any part of the examination and this should be documented in the report. The Sonographer should decide whether the patient is suitable for the examination if the patient is unable to understand what is involved. This would mean that the patient was not able to fully consent to the scan.
Carers may want to be involved as much as possible in the examination, for example in the moving and handling of the patient.
Help from carers should be encouraged by the Sonographer if the carer wants to participate and the patient gives their consent.
